comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: What can I say? "I remember it well?" It was a very sexist facility - the men had their needs met and the women could hold on to it?????  Note the far side of the Liffey - the Wood Quay site is derelict.  There is no sign of the bunker that desecrates one of the most historic sites in Dublin or of its later facelift.  Is there any chance you could turn it slightly so I can read the election poster?

comment._content:
I was only 9 or 10 at the time but distinctly remember that ornate structure. Wonder what happened to it - broken up for scrap iron maybe?

As part of a pergola, that cast-iron roof would make a magnificant garden feature.

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 36844288@N00
comment._content: I recall, from somewhere, that the french-style urinals were erected in Dublin for the 1932 Eucharistic Congress.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 36844288@N00
comment._content: Yes, Derry O'Connell's excellent 1975 book on Dublin street furniture "The Antique Pavement" mentions them as part of the 'spruce up Dublin' work prior to the 1932 Congress and they were placed along the Quays between the city centre and Phoenix Park. The last one I recall (c1984) was at Fairview at Malahide Road - well off the 'pilgrim route' - does it survive?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/36844288@N00] Don't know. Maybe Google Street View can be our friend. Wonder if there'll be much effort to spruce up Dublin before next June's Eucharistic Congress...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/36844288@N00] Hi Mike. Thank you for that reference, quite interesting. 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] I wouldn't hold your breath on that one! Ireland is a totally different place to what it was in 1932 and the same public enthusiasm just won't be there. Preparations are already in-hand but it will be a much more low-key and discreet affair.

A very happy Christmas to you both and all the best for the New Year.

Stuart.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03] And to you, Stuart! Looking forward to your comments, etc. in 2012...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: I visited the SS Great Britain at Bristol last week, and couldn't help noticing a Victorian quayside chalet de nécessité I collared a venerable guide, and asked him about it. He said that although most of the props on the quayside (cabin trunks, sacks of grain, porters' trolleys etc) had been brought in from elsewhere, the urinal was authentic and still in its original position. Moreover, unlike Brunel's workshops a few yards away, it had survived everything the Luftwaffe had thrown at it in 1941 (although I suspect that at one time it had a roof).
